document.title: STRANDS AND STANDARDS EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION 2

5DDF49DF96DE4EA499B1FA38DA9B6BA9.description: Provide children with choices and voting opportunities.

5F6212BCAC90440F81EF6B57D24680E2.description: Explain the importance of safety and why that practice is important.

F5687CFA86C74574899A4581686B4933.description: Model behaviors that care for the environment.

20A838CB8D03464B85B2F988ED02A87D.description: Design activities that foster social interaction.

E942223525354B8FB4383FC66F7ECC1D.description: Provide direct instruction on appropriate social interaction skills with specific feedback.

8DDE4480022244C3BDC37A40E6D81793.description: Acknowledge children’s efforts and classroom contributions.

E9DF2375DB944397ACFE312D3BA46E61.description: Encourage children to respect and include all classmates, appreciate differences, and meet one another’s needs.

FB32377529914926ACD5148B7BBB0F24.description: Honor children’s family culture and maintain a respectful attitude when interacting with others.

0880AB623AF845D2857A54702E83140A.description: Learn about children’s preferences, interests, background, and culture. Adults share information about themselves and find commonalities with children and others.

DDC448738A384124BCF338E70AA3B0BB.description: Techniques for supporting Physical Education include

D0DB549DEE964832B2F5B52407FB0B69.description:
The purpose of Social Studies is to prepare children to become informed and engaged citizens in a culturally
diverse, rapidly changing, and interdependent world

F46A7E2E9646475384FF0A98B1E5B6E6.description: Students will demonstrate how to support Social Studies for preschoolers.

AF26B12CB4A84586804E589EAAD30350.description: Support children’s curiosity in their exploration of their environment by encouraging problem solving and discovery.

D42B61F4A466484AB71E5954FD639427.description: Model and support vocabulary associated with the scientific process.

7D8F5A1BFA8F422F9F9FF9EA0A1FE723.description: Build ramps, forts, levers, etc. with children and let them discover what will happen when using them.

6A4BD247A4BF424ABCF40DACEA6421DB.description: Provide children with language to describe what they see, hear, touch, taste, etc.

FD3425380AAB4B8C969AFE19F2851203.description: Point out changes in children’s environment including the weather, seasons, etc.

747789C7276345CDA99890ECE4B036C7.description: Lead children in discussions of, “What do you think will happen if…?”

28331DF97345411A93FC06F9AF04F363.description: Allow children to explore their surroundings and ask questions while they are doing so.

44F1B907DED942E3AD8B6FFD21EF0F44.description: Pushing or pulling on an object can change the speed or direction of an object in motion.

9F5E282AF12D4790BFF2460E83C96BD2.description: All things are made of matter. Various kinds of matter, such as wood, metal, and water, have different properties that can be observed, described, and classified.

5DDBE02A14C64024BC6B050FCD06FD1F.description: Behavior patterns between parents and offspring can help animals, including humans, to survive.

A37FB8FF87C042E69DF89208A663BD24.description: Living things (plants and animals, including humans) depend on their surroundings to get what they need, including food, water, and shelter, to survive.

FCAB275A08F740E2A1462574FA8F2441.description:
Sunlight has an effect on surfaces. Objects can be seen when light is available to illuminate them.
Light is required for plant growth.

5C75762A208D450EA30AA25A6D1852EF.description: Weather: the combination of sunlight, wind, snow, or rain, and temperature in a particular place at a particular time. Humans can plan and prepare for different weather conditions.

B6F30342733B467D8CF2FEAC1974B3FA.description: Young children are captivated by discovering and exploring their natural world. They insist that teachers and family members answer their questions about the world around them

CD8ECC92787B4F9DB1604174036A0ECE.description: Students will demonstrate how to support Science for preschoolers.

5843C9D6D72142AF9BA6DC448D832FF9.description: Provide opportunities for both organized and spontaneous play.

CF52BC051CA3486D9EB09F3A09805DCF.description: Teach, model, and maintain proper safety rules.

5BDF2141728D45CEA5083FE942D04D4E.description: Participate in fine and gross motor activities alongside the children.

B1E2F5A375CD4878AB2DC085191B16B1.description: Practice building with large and small blocks, molding clay, using scissors or tongs, stringing beads, placing pegs in holes, assembling puzzles, using a computer mouse, and using a variety of writing utensils (pencils, crayons, markers) and art mediums (painting, printing, manipulating clay, stamping).

459F7841DB2E4D95A8541FC52C15A6CA.description: Run, gallop, throw, catch, hop, kick, dance, jump, climb, pull, carry, stretch, bend, twist, and move isolated parts of the body. `

17D4F2A111504B389D4F54BBFEF050D6.description:
Continually encourage, challenge, and strengthen children’s gross and fine motor skills by teaching,
modeling, and providing many opportunities to:

1E3266793A2E44858D20014EDC6B3419.description: Techniques for supporting Physical Education include

9878B6159B9F4D598184E4501F98E0DD.description: Non-locomotor skills include balancing on one foot, moving body parts in isolation, bending, twisting, turning.

7D0D2A61E17446E69D4F0E8522840678.description: Locomotor skills include walking, hopping, running, jumping, galloping, leaping, and sliding.

86505979F9A6488E8AD97D8C2B0BA267.description: Fine (small) motor skills, including the two-finger pincer grasp and manipulation of small objects, support the development of pre-writing skills.

26D84E617C1F43E1B15A5A5BA902E5B4.description: Gross (large) motor skills, including walking, kicking, hopping, galloping, running, sliding, skipping, leaping, and jumping, are the foundation of movement.

1A46F073092646E3B9BD06D5310AD60A.description: Motor skills are defined as both small muscle and large muscle movements.

329EC16F950B43249C66D3B470CCDEA7.description: As children refine their physical movements, they develop higher-order thinking skills that are necessary for future social and academic success.

9F9090B8CE92488FBD0E8DD93E7A3E88.description: Physical development is integral to building children’s self-esteem, confidence, fitness, and well-being.

082021979A394E67ABF22AEA5BACBE52.description: The goal of physical education is to develop healthy, responsible children who have the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to work together, think critically, and participate in a variety of activities that lead to a lifelong healthy lifestyle.

59C9AFE849C24B889210E23CB2815E9D.description: Students will demonstrate how to support Physical Education for preschoolers.

5C270232BF7A45B1B9F28E5202EBDFC9.description: Integrate mathematics throughout the day (for example, counting snacks, identifying shapes, ordering objects by length or size).

CA12390736554EB496DE201A8DDD97C5.description: Integrate mathematical experiences, including stories, chants, and songs to reinforce mathematical concepts such as “Five Little Speckled Frogs,” “Five Little Ducks,” and “The Three Billy Goats Gruff.”

EB271816BE7B4F7D86E5E8BA688DC96B.description: Use mathematical language to extend children’s understanding within the context of their experiences, such as: “Do you want half a glass of milk or a full glass of milk?” or “Would you like more or fewer grapes than I have?”

DCDD161CCAF04FEBA005666798818647.description: Design experiences where children explore and experience their environment to identify spatial relationships such as, “How many children fit inside the castle in the outdoor area?”

109273E7940B4B8AAB6D7441E89B4D1E.description: Give children adequate time to explore and experiment with manipulatives before starting teacher planned instruction.

48FBDBAC06974C758039C16F80A5B582.description: Geometry- the ability to identify, describe, compare, and create shapes.

1AC2592A152C456A842E38430A8C0181.description: Measurement and Data- the ability to describe and compare measurable attributes of objects, classify objects, and count the number of objects in each category.

49B266E5AD2F41BA819C7F94FF62CC91.description: Operations and algebraic thinking- identifying and manipulating simple patterns, the understanding of addition as putting together and adding to, and the understanding of subtraction as taking apart and removing from.

D0CC4C2E06EC430493B6AEDB47C14277.description: Counting and cardinality- the ability to identify numerals by name, count in sequence, use one-toone correspondence, and describe quantities of objects counted.

DDB11775BA4442A6A4CDE015D653B41C.description: Quality learning environments should focus on actual hands-on experiences during play and interaction with others to incorporate well-designed mathematical experiences.

3997FF2DC4DC42AFB4FE58B191B43838.description: Mathematics is a way of thinking about patterns, relationships, and seeking multiple solutions to problems.

CB480F0A22974EA1A540B0297A49BA88.description: Students will demonstrate how to support Mathematics for preschoolers.

3F0F8589A4844229A4C7B771F504A8AA.description: Acknowledge, respect, and validate children’s expression of all emotions as teaching opportunities.

C33889E70C494A92B81171A181AA5504.description: Design activities that require social interaction.

7CCD0BB793834423A22A5E4D74B44274.description: Provide direct instruction on appropriate social interaction skills.

5594206EA62F456183448373D37BE314.description: Embed opportunities throughout the day to provide positive, affirming, and supportive, feedback to children.

927544A4B6874EB7A1F0AF667477D8B0.description: Recognize and honor variations in cultural contexts relating to how children play and make sense of their experiences. Provide materials that are culturally relevant and inclusive of children that make up the learning community.

BE028FF681544E50A18E0D01970E2301.description: Create a learning environment that inspires a sense of wonder, delight, curiosity, and creativity.

A205E1EC69DE4701BFA400C123487077.description: Help children develop citizenship skills to be responsible, accountable, and helpful.

6809A3E4CEEC463DAA892E726E8FCCE2.description: Techniques for supporting Lifelong Learning Practices include

FFD2C8400DE249D584BC04B4AC717C72.description: Social development includes self-awareness, regulation and recognition of emotions, emotional responsiveness, managing stress, and the ability to interact with others effectively in social settings.

FB55CBC4C7484CDA978B31DBFA1CE986.description: Learning Engagement is the way children continue to develop the ability to actively explore and participate in the learning environment.

2FE91CF6EBD34CEEA8FCD88247A8D78C.description: Approaches to Learning includes the concepts of curiosity, engagement, interest in learning, independence, flexibility, perseverance, imagination, and problem-solving.

C2F7625DA24647C684DF63740FC6474B.description: Students will demonstrate how to support Lifelong Learning Practices for preschoolers.

683FD023B8D044BCBA68AC30A84AA9C5.description: Help children acknowledge their feelings and teach them appropriate ways to handle those feelings.

94AF44924E0D4B7BA5A076B02BDF8E0A.description: Talk about foods in the environment and discuss healthy foods during snack time.

A8BFE55FCA1E4DFB8A5D9A92633EF206.description: Provide suggestions for appropriate turn taking.

B41EF50CBF5846289732E4069FD7E066.description: Provide examples of what a good friend is and is not.

94F2DCDBC0C84183B8648C2598864ACB.description: Encourage the child to participate in self-care routines.

143736CC025445599D11996E5E8694F2.description: Techniques for supporting Health Education include

5E1B3B6778C145BF8203B122ADA7F5F0.description: Nutrition focuses on understanding the importance of nutritional food on health throughout life, including food choices, such as identifying healthy or less healthy foods, and how to properly fuel the body.

F6ED7797F40146008ED34A601B8733C4.description: Mental and Emotional Health focuses on awareness and care for the mental and emotional health of self and others.

E826C65B0D9543FA8AC60BF507F11DA2.description: Physical Health includes Independence in personal care and hygiene.

28D02BC446F8430FB96F803815BB23B7.description: The Health Education strands include physical, mental, emotional, and social health.

9D7CD322AD7743268F8DA4FF67F37ACA.description: Students will demonstrate how to support learning in Health Education for preschoolers.

88196FE574034689AA861096A0C9D15B.description: Value the process not the product

2E29E4D12E144279A6173DB3A97D4EFC.description: Provide open-ended art experiences- all mediums are used to create and explore. An opportunity for exploration and expression without a look-alike result is the goal.

7D5C96C0934D4D52A3026D08CDB4011F.description: Acknowledge children’s efforts and persistence in artistic expression.

D0D33B4101F147A3B46259CF8354E6FA.description: Engage and follow the children’s lead in creative processes.

BC898473A1A440CFB12A65ACD40BB0D7.description: Techniques for supporting Fine Arts include

CDEE2A7992F74CCD82AFB8FC7F1F0869.description: Engaging in fine arts reduces children’s stress and increases their cognition, self-awareness, selfdirection, social and cultural awareness, independence, language skills, physical and social-emotional development, and ability to make sense of the world around them.

6CF4C2DA88194E1685223AA86BC2C888.description: Musical experiences support understanding foundational mathematical concepts.

E7B74F1A1F3945CF929855274028C715.description: Visual arts instruction improves reading readiness.

0C5007ECF5F54418AB8E6EDCB85A31C2.description: Learning in Fine Arts is valuable for building curiosity and supporting children in expressing and communicating their ideas and experiences.

08593FE98789432FA74C6834B3A3D4AC.description: Visual arts provide sensory, expressive, and social opportunities through the use of various media and materials to create drawings, pictures, or 3D art

3EB776ADA5564445A1D1632D5C441699.description: Music offers students the opportunity to learn songs, create music, develop self-expression, and build cultural understanding with self and others.

44CB5BA0EF2046448F8162ED0E561A01.description: Dance provides children the opportunity to use their bodies to move to music and express themselves through movement.

B59B3DB741A542178734B1E7DFF80BC9.description: Drama provides creative opportunities for children to portray a variety of events, characters, or stories through taking on different roles, interacting with props, and engaging in dramatic interactions.

72483B78E3BB41CAB99459E36D8E669E.description: The Fine Arts strands includes drama, dance, music, and visual arts

61FE297457794FF79F1AFAB131369373.description: Students will demonstrate how to support learning in Fine Arts for preschoolers.

5318DC639D7045559E0AA938C1CA12BD.description:
Writing down what children say, labeling their drawings, writing questions that could be asked
of a visitor, or making a list of foods.

030CB29FFF5B4BE6BF909DD6A6AE4256.description: Supply a variety of age-appropriate writing tools and materials in all areas of the classroom, including thin short pencils, crayons, markers, whiteboards, glue sticks, magnetic letters, paintbrushes, etc.

EAEEB839DB7E4B458165213C35C91940.description: Encourage children to re-enact stories using dramatic play or puppets.

A66CDFEF7902415B85EE82F341BF8CE2.description: While reading to children, ask questions about what may happen next, how the book relates to their own experiences, how the characters in the story are feeling, etc.

8EF0F872549C42C6B9B73BBFFD798213.description: Provide opportunities for multiple readings/retellings of nursery rhymes or stories.

147BC49D70074C3B856D6869A797CC22.description: Clapping the syllables in children’s names or other familiar words.

726E41A2BF8E421F8973562F3938C547.description: Provide activities that increase awareness of the rhythm of language

D7A5A5AF2ECD49B5A1C96E8473A4F0EE.description: menus, books, magazines, charts, newspapers, maps, instruction booklets, labels, and store flyers

1C86DBCC6A984E249A1B7423F945BEF1.description: Provide a variety of texts representative of languages spoken in the classroom

68CCFFD105194A9FBE7F6CA0DDD9E42C.description: Sing a wide variety of songs

BED7958B04CB48F59A037FF60148A8DB.description:
Animated and engaging storytelling, pictures or drawings, posters, appropriate short multimedia
presentations, drama, show and tell, signs, paintings, sculptures, puppets, and hand signs.

8CA38BD1F70B4491AF819A61BA7D5D54.description: Use a wide variety of media and presentation forms

4BDF613C34784743AC328F228D038172.description: Provide activities that increase phonological awareness.

BF1DA13C8F54401CA71BBD4BCD6DD639.description: Reading, listening, writing, and dramatic play centers, eye level alphabet charts, picture/word labels, and samples of children’s work.

4EC34837E95645A9A70ABAC05AEA0BCA.description: Create a language- and print-rich environment

50F073AFE19343AC858BBA628C24C330.description: Read daily from a variety of texts, including narrative and informational genres.

EADCDA192BE94AA997F8F26FE378403C.description: Language is the basis for understanding and communicating in most aspects of life.

5DBF93D4F74C481BACF1E5D4ACF5575B.description: Literacy enables students to participate fully in their community and society.

AAACEF7AF9964F9FA29D2036C2F47893.description: Literacy is the ability to read, write, speak, and listen.

A6A617C9706D4E898920220C55A3206B.description: The English Language Arts strands includes speaking and listening, reading, and writing

15BB1788BDB640BDBDD25621749487F7.description: Students will demonstrate how to support learning in English Language Arts for preschoolers.

9B8C9176FBD644CF9301084EAC21A79A.description:
Explore the Utah Core Standards for Early Learning
https://www.schools.utah.gov/file/2f5c23cd-43cc-4ab1-b5d7-ef1f918362e9

68B1C31A7F944743BB2A8121F8A26BA9.description: Containers and shelves are child sized and labeled with words and pictures to support independence and language skills.

85BC6FE9037D4AF0A9EA39AFFEA4CC83.description: The space should be inclusive (multicultural, non-sexist, differing abilities) through books, pictures and learning materials

1F22C4EDE7E2480DBD059052329F4301.description: Children should have ownership in the space (ex. children’s artwork displayed at their eye level)

0E45CBA55A0540EEA55C1B6EA32A5E28.description: Space should be welcoming, pleasing to the eye and safe

112E8FEB94134DD6A6C9CEB3054740BD.description: Centers are defined and include a quiet/calming space where a child can be alone

83849F45B06D43498C58C8180CFAB611.description: Children will be inclined to act appropriately if the space is orderly and organized with a place for everything

B6DFBD4CEC034D90A905B61510B52FDD.description: Everything in your space, including furniture, materials and supplies set the tone for the class

473DF8F4762A4828A9E71590A72BBDEC.description: Novelty Cues- involve the use of unusual or new actions and devices to move the children from one activity to the next (asking a question, tiptoeing to the door)

43AF1B7D27474B29A2F72409670303B4.description: Auditory Cues- sounds used to move children from one area to another (clean up song, ringing a bell)

25CDF409B72243718F6429139CBF7B18.description: Visual Cues- items are used that the child can see to inform them of a change in activity (when you see your name you may go, turning off the lights)

AF5EF3FA1AA243FA94155059368E0747.description: Concrete Cues- objects move from one place to another (hang up your coat as you go inside, tuck in your chair)

7CD2424EFB3C40058DC5BB17A20DE644.description: Transitions- the process of moving from one lesson, space, or event to another during the school day

6DB063D718D64F16BEF37510C8AB5324.description: Reflection/evaluation- a review of the activity including: any changes, children’s learning, teacher’s learning.

B2E924BEF04D4045918153CB29244298.description: Rationale- explains how the activity benefits the child

52451D83B871482EBE8499952702557E.description: Supplies- materials needed to complete the activity

C3F84E3DBD714DCCB321E2E5F6CB5802.description: Procedure- Step by step instructions for implementing the activity

A95B57DBD4484750A8D5F70D510CFCDA.description: Standard- concise written descriptions of what students are expected to know and be able to do at a specific stage of their education.

8BA5D07EB998410E99B414F5B5D21B5B.description: Objective- The overall goals that children may learn, know and/or do.

919B4B0BC8EA4AD8AA6E044F28431522.description: Lesson Plan- A description of the activity that includes goals and procedure

1D5A364210994AAFBE0E5AED075CA02A.description: Review the components of a lesson plan.

8731A7F126074A65ABF2F6F1E2141980.description:
Small Group Time (teacher led individualized support)- encourages children to explore and experiment with new or familiar materials, skills and ideas that adults have selected based on their daily observations of children’s interests, the developmental milestones, the Utah Early Childhood Core Standards,
and local events.

F4048E46969243D3B4DF6BF5839E1003.description: Whole Group Time (teacher led)- a time when children come together as a community of learners to share their thoughts, listen to one another, actively participate together and build a sense of respect and support for one another.

E6D0F9F19AF940988F6BFCCF3A6F94C4.description: Learning Centers (child-directed and teacher supported play)- purposeful way of dividing the classroom into different subject or learning areas (i.e., dramatic play, sensory, blocks, writing, etc.)

EAF192F3E6BE48A3821D32F9B0FB530C.description: Routines- steps needed to complete each part of the schedule, provides structure and security.

A65D14845C894003A7435397733A78C5.description: Daily schedule- represents the big picture and includes main activities that happen across the day.

2261D274AF33466E80A44E462969458E.description: Themes- A main topic, idea, or concept around which the classroom activities are planned.

DA571D8FBAB144BF9FA930309531431F.description: Scope and sequence-a summary of content to be taught and the order it will be taught

7032B5B3D1C44F2C9AD0BC0A39D8F573.description: Understand calendaring, daily scheduling/routines, learning centers and group time.

B6C277473950446FBE2518116893D3E2.description: Students will create developmentally appropriate curriculum for young children.

CB7D069CEDCC4DE1B8CA8F0E6227EC4B.description:
Support Teacher: Help with activities, crowd control, preparation, and anticipate classroom/lead
teacher needs. Make activity idea suggestions. Fulfill assignments of preparing activities from the lead
teacher. Get involved in the activities and support the children. Help with clean-up and evaluating the
day’s activities.

3A8730BBCBBE463F93857B1A867A3744.description: Professionalism (e.g. involve and direct support teachers to help with lessons and activities, crowd control, preparation, etc. Clean up and complete an evaluation of the day)

395B52DF784342FEB4E51BEA1154A732.description: Planning and implementing curriculum (e.g. create the daily plan for the class.)

F6E57BBF033F44EE99ED954185FE5D86.description: Teaching to enhance each child’s development (e.g. Responsible for the pace and order of the lessons)

410C40570962455C96E867D216780B9D.description: Establishing partnerships with families (e.g. home to school connection)

1AFB5209CBFB449DA347EE72FFBAF158.description: Creating a caring, equitable and developmentally appropriate community of learning (e.g. supervision of children, anticipate the needs of the children.)

A0CB3A6429764C51BD8AC975597F03DB.description: Identify and/or demonstrate the responsibilities of the lead and support teacher.

5B066EA9B77642968C986B811E047686.description: Students will explore the responsibilities of early childhood educators.

70E097951B0B4064973D993C6477EF08.description: What do I do with this information?

964476B10B084FF7ACFCD8B3C4B7E2B3.description: Use completed observations to develop relationships with children and learning activities

006001E9180A4950BFA10E35AFC6F486.description: Evaluate and interpret observations to guide teaching practices.

C73B5DF4DB8F4F1AAD0C94F0DB8A29CE.description: “Johnny did not want to build with blocks, I don’t think he likes playing blocks, so he sat and stared at them.”

0ADFD9CD86C34B48BD50F8943CC915DC.description: Subjective/interpretive statements- rely on personal opinions, assumptions, and feelings about the behavior that has been observed.

E5813C789020432C98EF737EA3B9184E.description: “Johnny sat and stared at the blocks before he began to build with them.”

35AAA38AB3664855AC5E46828AADC349.description: Objective/factual statements- statements that rely on and are based on the solid facts as a foundation. They focus only on what you can see and hear.

6FE02F6A8AFE4D0F80FB8523F61FB7F2.description: Explore your own personal biases in the early childhood education classroom and how they affect an observation.

E62985C8B6404DCA9599B9C1695FDC47.description: Explore objective and subjective statements in observations and personal biases.

B89CF45B2504457CB36B68FF4609D37E.description: Interview — questioning children or families to gain information

85ABF524FE40494698F63598742F62A9.description: Work Sample—examples of children’s work, photos, video etc.

1C7DA0CB09F4491FA93F23D067A2FEF0.description: Frequency count—records the number of times something happens (e.g. how many times a child bites or is aggressive to another child) during a specified time period (e.g. hour or day) during a specified time period (e.g. hour or day)

8643B07C255C457A998E47BB03A7A7C9.description: Checklist—gather observational information about children’s skills, behaviors, or attitudes (e.g. developmental milestones)

EF56A4D40FC847E38ACAD4A47CAF91FE.description: Anecdotal—short, recorded descriptions of incidents involving one or more children to provide data on a child’s interests, interactions, and progress

F35FD6D9448440408804157852240929.description: Informal Assessments: observing children in the classroom, collecting samples of their work, interviewing parents, and talking with children

05291AB4451043D2BBEBAA19BA85350B.description: Formal Assessments: include standardized tests and research instruments, recording data on carefully designed forms, and analyzing and interpreting data

8E93E8D436B34B5DADDF119D2E5B0286.description: Assessment- Evaluation or estimation of the nature, quality or ability of someone or something

EA424FF67E454B26888479CF3CD46EA4.description: Explore a variety of observation tools used in early childhood education.

A1ACBD26A4FF4A0BA27B5EE0DB533510.description: Participant Observer: someone who interacts with the children while observing

81B72533C5044491AAD98B2592C0C7F1.description: Naturalistic Observer: watches children and records their natural behaviors as they occur

68EEE6CE4F7D498F93CEEB8BBC74CD97.description: Identify how best to challenge and support children, to scaffold learning

2A73BF7427AA4782BD5334EBB65B3C3B.description: Understand the child and their experience in the classroom, to better respond and interact with them

C9DB05F5D7334796AA5C35DE306BF90E.description: Fundamental tool to support awareness of a child’s development, skills, interests, strengths, and play

AC010048DD6A497E85399C5CE76FEF85.description: Observation - Watching children with the clear goal of studying or understanding how they are feeling, learning and thinking.

A320FDB5902D4382919FB26D184A1242.description: Understand the purposes of early childhood observations

C9F82ACDA1A240C094309F34B5FB97F9.description:
Students will complete and incorporate observations to strengthen every aspect of an early childhood
program.
Incorporate observation techniques and guidelines while studying children and developing strategies to meet
their needs.
